Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2007 08:31AM chemomom wrote: I haven't started rads yet (will in Jan) but I heard good things about Crystal Body Deodorant and ordered it from Amazon, cheaper than the Crystal site online.  I am trying it out now and hopefully it is working!!
Posts.Title: Deordorant during rads ilenee Binney4

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2007 08:28AM chemomom wrote: OK gals, I had drainage too, as one of my drains actually got plugged and had to be pulled early.  Just a bit of advice I got from the NP at the doc's-- if the drainage gets to be such that it is soaking your gauze more than you'd like... she said to try taping a sanitary napkin over the site.  they are clean and much more absorbant.  Sounds very weird... but it did work when I wanted to be sure I didn't get fluid all over.  BC makes us do weird stuff!!
Posts.Title: Drainage at Tube Removal Site golfer779 golfer779

Posts.Content: chemomom wrote: Hi ladies,  I had a bilateral mastectomy on 10/25 with no reconstruction.  I just managed to look at myself without bandages today (hooray- i am very proud about that!).  I guess i was not expecting things to be as "lumpy" as they are.  Is it really normal to have "hills and valleys" at this point?  The NP who took out one of my drains assured me everything looked fine.  But I had been planning on going without breast-forms and I don't see how I will be able to wear regular clothes once the bandages are off.  If the irregular shapes of my chest really is probably normal, then how long should I expect before it starts to look a little flatter?  I will admit I am chubby and I used to have very large breasts, so maybe those factors have contributed to the results thus far.  But if you could let me know if you had a similar experience after mast I would really appreciate it.  And if you have any tricks for hiding the irregularities once you're back in regular clothes I could really use those too.  I am supposed to go back to work in another 2 weeks and I don't know what I'll do to try not to look deformed.  Thanks in advance... Angie Dx 7/16/2007, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Can I go form-free after bilateral mastectomy? chemomom Erica

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2007 08:20AM chemomom wrote: Bimmer, I only know you and Diane thru the words of your heartfelt posts but the love you had for each other was loud and clear.  I am very sorry for the loss your family has suffered.  My thoughts will be with you and your family as you work thru this very difficult time.  Angie
Posts.Title: Very advanced B.C.: Diane's final gift. Bimmer ilenee

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 06:55PM chemomom wrote: Here's my anecdote for the day... I had my 2nd actual treatment today (after Wednesday's surprise of additional mappings).  I am in a smallish town and at the Rads place I go to, I only ever deal with this one guy for tx.  I have no idea what all the nurses milling about do there-- i haven't dealth with a single one of them.  So anyway, i was asking numerous questions about which areas are getting treated and I was really surprised that the guy actually touched me while I was laying there.  Skin on skin, illustrating what would happen.  It is funny to me, since I haven't even had my husband touch my chest since my bilateral mast.  It didn't make me "uncomfortable" so much as I was just not used to that.  Funny how my male OBGYN always had to have  a "chaperone" when I had a check-up.  Apparently I am a-sexual now and it is not an issue for a rads guy.  Oh well.  And by the way, I am being a rebel and using a crystal deodorant in the morning since I am at work both before and after tx.  I'll let you know how it turns out.  Maybe I have it "easy" since I had a bilateral mastectomy and have nothing left to be modest about, but if you can get past laying around topless for a while, rads seems like a cake-walk.  But like Miss Lolli said... remind me of that in a month, when the area formerly known as my ta-tas is on fire (and all because I used regular body-wash and a crystal deodorant!!).  Have a nice weekend gals, Angie
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2008 07:12PM chemomom wrote: Hi all,  Like nash, i also reported my terrible pains from this weekend to my rad onc today.  He also had no idea what could have caused it.  "Certainly not radiation alone."   Of course.  That's why the area formerly known as my right boobie and underarm-- exactly where all the sharpie marks go, just happened to swell up to a god-awful size and turn pink and hurt like a son-of-a gun.  He asked if i had been "doing anything different" with my arm.  Ummmm, no.  And his best idea was that it was maybe due to having Herceptin while also having radiation, since I had my first Herceptin-only tx thurs of last week.  Anyone heard of that??  I don't think I believe that one.  Time may tell. But he gave me today off from rads.  Back tomorrow though and I am scared.  But of course. my rad onc is pretty sure I will not have a reaction again.  It's just too soon.  Wish me luck ladies.  I am so sick of all of this!!!  ARRGGHHHHH!! Glad to hear many of you are doing just fine.  Sometimes the only positive vibes i can muster are the ones I get from here.  Stay strong ladies... somehow we will get thru this.
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2008 03:21PM chemomom wrote: Hi all.  I thought I ought to put in an update.  Come to find out, my crazy swollen rads area was really caused by a seroma.  (no idea why I had so much pain initially) .  I went to see my regular onc on Thurs and she took one look at me and figured it out.  And my surgeon came down and drianed it.  Not quite 200cc's I think.  And my skin is only a bit pink after 10 tx but I have already had to skip 2 tx's due to the seroma-mystery.  And Mon, I have to have a new CT so they can re-measure everything.  I have to stay wrapped in Ace bandages or the fluid starts coming back.  So much fun.
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2008 11:23PM - edited Mar 6, 2008 11:24PM by chemomom I'm done too!  Hooray.  Somehow I finally finished rads. Methusala when you mentioned your blog I went and checked it out.  I had TERRIBLE burns as well.  I literally had no skin and looked like a sirloin steak from the middle of my (flat) chest all the way to my back.  Luckily, I still have so much numbness from my mast that I didn't have to deal with much pain.  Sorry you are having to deal with the pain as well.    I had to take an entire week off of rads , since it was so bad.  But I was given silvadine cream like Abbi.  I plastered it on and it helped tremendously.  If the stuff they gave you doesn't seem to be working, or fast enough, maybe ask for the silvadine. And I had to be careful to dress the area with non-stick gauze, since I tore the healed tissue off if I didn't.  It is gross-- for me, before it scabbed and healed, the area was either covered in a mucus-like stuff or even sometimes just bled at the touch (this lasted about 2 weeks).   It is horrible, but what they are saying is true-- it does heal quickly once you are done messing with that area.  I just finished today, but the week break helped A LOT.  And you're not alone.  Don't forget that.
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2008 12:06PM chemomom wrote: Hi all,  I went to my first rads appt yesterday.  I didn't get a tx though.  The dude said something about needing to do more films and setting up an electron field to intensify the radiation in certain areas.  I have no idea what any of it meant, really.  I go back today, but I am not sure if I will have a tx or what will happen.  I am covered in sharpie marks  again, but that's about the extent of things so far.  I asked again about lung damage and weakening of the bones and the person that would have been doing the radiation said again that neither of those things will happen.  And they said to put nothing on the skin.  So this dude is saying things that are very different from what I have heard here.  Here's hoping they know what they are doing.......    Angie
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 05:57PM chemomom wrote: Hey shrink, funny you should ask.  i have had 7 tx and am pink already as well.  And while the skin itself doesn't hurt, I am having a great deal of pain-- i am imagining my insides being cooked, basically.  The pain came on after tx7 yesterday as the day went on.  And by evening I could barely move.  I had heard rads would be a breeze.  This is no breeze.  By the way, when I told the rad guy I thought I was pinking up, he did give me some Aquaphor.  At that time I wasn't in pain or anything. I am hoping these 2 days off allow me to get a bit better.  And just when you think a mastectomy site can't look any worse, it turns pink (scar is red) and swells up.  Ahh cancer, so much fun...       Angie

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2007 09:18AM chemomom wrote: I am 32 and am the only one in my family to have had breast cancer.  Since I am so young, though I was able to get the BRCA testing covered by insurance.  My ins co sent me their criteria for BRCA coverage and while a dx at a young age was one reason they covered the tests, they also covered testing for people that had immediate family members with a history of breast or ovarian cancer. I would suggest you call your insurance company and ask them to provide their BRCA coverage policy.  In your situation, I would think that it is more likely the sheer number of relatives in your family with a history of breast cancer that would qualify you for coverage, rather than any age considerations.  Best of luck to you and your family.
Posts.Title: Age and BRCA testing corepat veggievet

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2007 08:21AM chemomom wrote: lisa54,  I work at a hospital and the Durable Medical Equpiment arm of the facility actually has a boutique and breast form fitters for post-mastectomy women.  Maybe checking around at the hospitals in your area might help you find something similar.  i went to see what they offered and they did seem like decent forms.  I still decided to go "flat" but I also has a bilateral, so I didn't have to worry about "matching."  best of luck.  Angie

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2007 03:32AM - edited Dec 21, 2007 03:33AM by chemomom I also had the mold made, but just of my legs.  And I find the tattoos to be very disappointing-- I don't have any others and I only have one where I can attempt to look at it and it is the tiniest darn thing!  I wanted to "show them off."  :)  I couldn't feel the 2 on my sides-- still numb from surgery. I just had my last chemo and the rad onc had said start 2 weeks after tx but my regular onc said wait three, so I'll be starting maybe around 1/10 (also my first Herceptin only tx).  And I think I was told I'd have about 7 weeks.  Not really sure yet though.  I ordered a crystal deodorant stick from Amazon as I was told no regular deodorant, powder, etc under the arm to be treated by the rad onc.  Since I am staring back to work... I don't want to take any chances, even though I have also heard that rads prevents any stinkies from perspiration.  Other than that, I didn't get many tips.  Angie

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2008 12:59PM chemomom wrote: I am also late finding this thread but wanted to chime in, as well.  I am slightly under a year from my bilateral mast.  I have no recon and no prosthetics.  I could hardly be happier.  I wanted to put in my 2 cents since last year, when I was looking around, it seemed that the choices were either recon or prosthetics and I was an oddball for wanting neither.  So I am really pleased to have found at least a few other brave souls that are boobless and beautiful!  I was very large-breasted before so that certainly colored my opinions to begin with, but I can't even tell how happy I am with my decision.  In my case, I have 2 young kids and I wanted no more problems (from recurrence or recon!!), so that was also a big part.  I am now a jogger and am finding I can live a much healthier lifestyle without boobs to worry about! The scars in my situation are extensive (I have about a 1/4 inch in the center of my chest that didn't get a scar and both sides go almost all the way around my sides (again-- I was large).  But over time, the scars and swelling are lessening.  I also often wear an undershirt or cotton sport bra to help keep what I have left from showing thru.  And while I have felt fine being boobless, I am not "proud" of the scars and I am just now starting to feel "comfortable" letting my husband see me without a top. But it's coming along. So there are options out there and I am 100% happy with my no recon & no prosthetics decision.  It's totally a personal decision.  Good luck to all who come along having to face these choices like we did.
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2007 03:38PM - edited Nov 19, 2007 03:41PM by chemomom Hi ladies.  I am 32, married, and have 2 young boys (5 & 2).  I had a bilateral mast on 10/25/07 (1 needed, 1 prophylactic).  I was very large chested before but I opted to go without recon.  Initially 2 reasons, really-- with 2 kids, I just wanted to get rid of the cancer and get on with healing.  Recon would only prolong recovery time.  Also, in my opinion, if I had gotten recon, it would have been entirely for other people.  Reconstructed boobs would look alien to me and most likely I wouldn't even be able to feel them.  So I didn't see the point.  For these same reasons, I don't bother with prostheses either.  At this point, closing in on a month after my surgery, I am very pleased with my decisions.  My boobs tried to kill me.  I am glad to be rid of them!  I may end up seeing a plastic surgeon to clean up the incision sometime in the future (we'll see as it continues to heal), but i do not see reconstruction or prosthetics in my future at all.  As an aside, I have found very little info on gals like me who opt to go without recon or prosthetics.  Even the NP's I see at the breast care center all assume everyone would want one or the other.  But for me, bra-free is the way to be.
Posts.Title: No reconstruction- Happy w/your decision? marlee1 quietpools
